unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: A. P. Exam Scores - Are They Independent?
question_text: Sam has been studying really hard for both the A. P. Calculus exam and the A. P. Statistics exam. He feels very confident that he will get either a $4$ or $5$ on the Statistics exam and that he will get at least a $3$ on the Calculus exam. Sam has estimated the joint probabilities associated with the two exams and his estimates are shown in the table below. A.P. Calculus Scores 5 4 3 A.P. Statistics 5 0.3 0.2 0.1 4 0.2 0.1 0.1 Based on these probabilities, are the scores that Sam will achieve on the two exams independent? Why or why not?

choices.text: Yes. The scores are independent because Calculus and Statistics are two totally separate courses and two totally separate exams.
Yes. They are independent because the probability of getting a 5 5 on the Statistics exam does not change even if we already know that Sam gets a 5 5 on the Calculus exam.

Yes. They are independent because the probability of getting a 5 5 on the Calculus exam and a 4 4 on the Statistics exam is the same as the probability of getting a 5 5 on the Statistics exam and a 4 4 on the Calculus exam.
No. They are not independent because the probability of getting a 5 5 on the Statistics exam changes if we know that the score on the Calculus exam is a 4 4 .
No. They are not independent because there are 3 3 possible outcomes on the Calculus exam but only 2 2 possible outcomes on the Statistics exam.
